Title: If $\alpha$ is an acute angle, show that $\int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x^2+2x\cos{\alpha}+1} = \frac{\alpha}{2\sin{\alpha}}.$
Content: If $\alpha$ is an acute angle, show that $\displaystyle  \int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x^2+2x\cos{\alpha}+1} = \frac{\alpha}{2\sin{\alpha}}.$ My attempt: Write $x^2+2x\cos{\alpha}+1 = (x+\cos{\alpha})^2+1-\cos^2{\alpha} = (x+\cos{\alpha})^2+\sin^2{\alpha}$, we have: $\displaystyle  \begin{aligned}\int_0^1 \frac{dx}{x^2+2x\cos{\alpha}+1} & = \int_0^1 \frac{dx}{(x+\cos{\alpha})^2+\sin^2{\alpha}} = \bigg[\frac{1}{\sin{\alpha}}\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{x+\cos{\alpha}}{\sin{\alpha}}\right)\bigg]_{x=0}^1 \\ & = \frac{1}{\sin{\alpha}}\bigg[\color{blue}{\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{1+\cos{\alpha}}{\sin{\alpha}}\right)-\tan^{-1}\left(\frac{\cos{\alpha}}{\sin{\alpha}}\right)}\bigg] \end{aligned}$ I'm not sure, however, how the blue bit reduces to $\frac{1}{2}\alpha$. Any hints/suggestions? Thanks.
